fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:fullName: ISO/IEC 11172. Information technology -- Coding of moving pictures and associated audio for digital storage media at up to about 1,5 Mbit/s (formal name), MPEG-1 (common name)
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:description: Compression encoding for video that may be accompanied by audio, identical to ITU-T (International Telecommunications Union-Telecommunication Standardization Sector) recommendation H.261. Low bandwidth, originally developed to store video on media like CDs; later widely used in online environments.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: Compression encoding for video that may be accompanied by audio, identical to ITU-T (International Telecommunications Union-Telecommunication Standardization Sector) recommendation H.261.

fdd:localUse.fdd:experience: Used extensively for access copies of American Memory reformatted moving image content, ca. 1990-2010.
fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: For preservation reformatting, the Library of Congress' Packard Campus for Audio-Visual Conservation has chosen MPEG-2, Main Profile (lossless JPEG 2000 wrapped in MXF operational pattern 1a).

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: Open standard. Developed through ISO technical program JTC 1/SC 29 for coding of audio, picture, multimedia and hypermedia information by Working Group 11 (WG11) aka the Moving Picture Experts Group (MPEG).
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: ISO/IEC 11172; first approvals in 1991. Five parts have been published; parts 1, 2, and 3 are central. See list of ISO documents in Format specifications below.

fdd:adoption.p: Widely adopted for filemaking and World Wide Web access. Many software tools exist for encoding and decoding.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: Depends upon algorithms and tools to read; will require sophistication to build tools.

fdd:selfDocumentation.p: Technical (coding) information is contained in the MPEG-1 bitstream in various headers. Image height and width, for example, are embedded within the sequence header.
The lack of metadata of the type called descriptive by librarians motivated the MPEG group to develop MPEG-7, a separately standardized structure for metadata to support discovery and other purposes.

fdd:movingImageQF.fdd:clarity: Moderate. Typical files have a picture size of 352x240 pixels (non-square pixels) and a data rate of 1.5 Mb/s, which means that only field of each video frame is captured. One commentator (http://www.faqs.org/faqs/mpeg-faq/part1/) reports that the source input format (SIF) for MPEG-1 "is CCIR-601 [component video] decimated by 2:1 in the horizontal direction, 2:1 in the time direction, and an additional 2:1 in the chrominance vertical direction. And some lines are cut off to make sure things divide by 8 or 16 where needed." Outcome will depend on the type and extent of compression, and the encoder used.

fdd:soundQF.fdd:fidelity: Moderate, given that this is a format for compression. Audio layer three encoding in the standard is also known as MP3_ENC. Outcome will depend on the type and extent of compression, and the encoder used.
fdd:soundQF.fdd:channels: MP3 supports five main channels and an optional LFE (Low Frequency Encoding or Effects) channel, i.e., 5.1 surround sound.

fdd:filenameExtension.fdd:note: There is no explicit MPEG-1 file format; MPEG-1 content "ready to be delivered" is exchanged in a de facto file format that may carry one of these extensions.

fdd:notes.fdd:history: MPEG stands for the Moving Picture Experts Group, which began developing video compression standards in the 1980s. The group was founded by two men described by one commentator as "the fiery Leonardo Chiariglione (CSELT, Italy)" and "the peaceful Hiroshi Yasuda (JVC, Japan)." MPEG's initial development was partly inspired by the H.261 video coding standard published by the ITU (International Telecom Union).

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: Many RFCs have been issued in relation to registration of MIME types for audio and video. The MIME type video/mpeg is listed by IANA as registered in 1996 in RFC 2046, one of a set of RFCs issued in relation to MIME (Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions). Other MPEG-2 related media types are listed as registered in 2003 through RFC 3555, one of payloads for RTP (Real-time Transport Protocol) payload formats. RFCs 2046 and 3555 are available from IETF (Internet Engineering Task Force) both as plain text and in a view that provides links to antecedent and subsequent documents.
